title: The Oracle of Oxford finds his star has fallen, but who can investors trust now?
text:
Two and a half years ago, Britain’s largest fund supermarket Hargreaves Lansdown said there were just three rules when it came to identifying a “star” fund manager. One, assess their experience. Second, crunch the numbers and, three, hold a face-to-face interview with the manager to understand what drives them. It seems that if they passed this test, fund managers could earn themselves a spot on Hargreaves’ “Best Buy” list of recommended funds.

Neil Woodford passed this test so frequently he not only earned himself repeat spots on the Hargreaves list, but an array of other superlative nicknames: Britain’s answer to Warren Buffett. The Oracle of Oxford. The man who made Middle England rich. Woodford,...
